SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

A brief explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada can answer all questions accurately. The answers given will not be exact, but they will give an idea of what life was like.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

1. Your full name: Robert Charles Sanderson
2. Your address: #314 Valle Vista, San Diego, Cal., U.S.A.
3. Date: May 15th, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): South St Mary, Ontario, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Robert Sanderson, Store Keeper & Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 1882
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   Winnipeg 1873-75, Delkota 1875-1882
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.):
   Six years old
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Because my dad did
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
    There were no railroads when we first came west. My maternal grandfather and uncle were prisoners of Blue in his first rebellion.
Robert Charles Sanderson
4314 Valle Vista, San Diego, Cal.

9. What was your occupation?
   Farmer

Because my dad did

10. How did you learn about the mission? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

This was my mother's when we first came west. My paternal Grandfather and uncle were prisoners of war in this first mission.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   by family coming to Winnipeg by myself in Indian Head

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Came to halfway between Brandon & Indian Head by train walked the rest of the way there was no railroad at that time

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   In a shack my father and neighbor John Stephens had built on John Stephens homestead seven miles north of Indian Head

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Homesteaded seven miles north of Indian Head along side of my father

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Traveled all over southern Saskatchewan buying horses from the ranchers raised cattle then send cattle on the farm

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   My dad fed me till I got to Sask then my brother and I worked out till we got a start, I around Calgary and in the mines west of there

Got married to Helen, First of 18th, 1908, died Sept 5th 1951

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Mother, Sister & Brother came April 1875
Father came in March 1875 went back & came again in April 1876

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I rode a team in 1885 in the Red Rebellion was at Fish creek and Balboche, I worked a bull, had some thru the top of General Middleton cap at fish creek and the staffing was shooting out behind and there was a settling gun there. I had met Red and most of the rebels they had come into my dads store at Selkirk, had come into my dads store at Selkirk, knew Horrie who defended Red, his father and uncle very well.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Travelled a lot between 1887 and 1909 south of CPR Railway in the ranch country buying horses to sell to the farmers east of Moose Jaw

Mother, Sister & Brother came April 8th went back same again ed 1887

Father came in October 8th went back

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

We were a team in 1885 in the Red River Valley at Headingley and Redvers. I worked a year at Headingley and then the CPR started a crop of wheat and the planting was phabulous. I had met Reil and there was a good deal of wheat. I had come into my land a type of Reil's and knew Reil who also knew Reil, his father and uncle very well.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? by what means of travel?

Travelled a lot between 1887 and 1909 mostly by CPR Railway in the spring country buying horses, seed & the former east & west farm.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1901/2

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   1912, a one-hander Cadillac

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Indian Head, seven miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Traded there from 1882 till we left in 1914. We had seven farms of 4600 acres.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once a week

   About 1912, a local cooperative company

   As I was young did not consider if I should stay or leave

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

None except those who sold their farms to some one else or men who worked on farms going other places to get farms mostly homesteads.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Wasn't there left for here in 1914

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

The Saskatchewan Grain Growers Association was started in our house. Bill Motherrill later the Hon. W.R. Motherrill minister of agriculture for the province and dominion was both president and John Miller managing director for about three years then I was managing director for about four years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given. Date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Indian Head got its name from a skeleton that was turned up when they were grading the railroad and they threw the head to our side. Major Bell of the Bell Farm told me he thought it would be a good advertisement for the town site he was going to survey and for the station and had the railway officials name it Indian Head.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some except those who sold their farms
& some are the men who worked on farms
& some other places & got farms nearby home

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

We went there first for two in 1914

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

The Secretary-Treasurer, William Armstrong, was elected in our town. Billy McPherson was elected in our town. Billy McPherson was elected in our town. Billy McPherson was elected in our town. Billy McPherson was elected in our town.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "migratory" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

When I was working down there for about four years

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Indian Head got its name from a settlement that was turned up when they were looking for the railroad and they drew the land off. It was named after the Bell of the West Farm and was the only farm in the area. It was a good adobe house and for the town site it was springy and sandy and hard the prevailing climate made it an ideal place.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Little change except turning the prairie into a wheat field.
Of course when we came to Fort Garry over Winnipeg there were no railroads.
